unit: Unit 8 | Inference for Categorical Data: Chi-Square
title: Chi-Square Goodness of Fit: Voter Population
question_text:
A politician projects that the population of voters who support him will be evenly divided between younger voters, middle-aged voters, and older voters. The table below shows the distribution of a random sample of 120 of the politician's supporters.
What is the value of the ${ \chi }^{ 2 }$ statistic for the goodness of fit test on these data?
What is the value of the ${ \chi }^{ 2 }$ statistic for the goodness of fit test on these data?
solution:
The formula to find the test statistic for ${ \chi }^{ 2 }$ is:

$$\sum { { \frac { \text{(Observed-Expected)} }{ \text{Expected} } }^{ 2 } } $$

The problem states the politician expects the percentage of his supporters to be evenly divided among the three groups. In this case the expected number of supporters for each group will be $\frac { 120 }{ 3 } =40$.

Substitute the values into the ${ \chi }^{ 2 }$ formula:

$${ \frac { (27-40) }{ 40 } }^{ 2 }+{ \frac { (34-40) }{ 40 } }^{ 2 }+{ \frac { (59-40) }{ 40 } }^{ 2 }=14.15$$
